reviewTitle: A Budget Monitor that Mostly Works OK - Not Recommended
reviewDescription: I have had this monitor for only a few days, and I am not very impressed with it.  The monitor control buttons being in the back where you have to blindly feel for them and just remember which one is which is a terrible design.  All of my other monitors have the buttons under the front edge where they are so much easier to use.  Having two HDMI inputs is nice, but the actual steps to switch between inputs are cumbersome, and the speed to switch screens is slow.  Not a big deal for the occasional change, but if you want to switch between inputs frequently while sitting at your desk, this is not a good monitor.The worst thing MAY be the speakers  - they are absolute garbage in both sound quality and volume (but see the last paragraph about the screen flashing on and off).  Turning up the volume in system settings on the monitor does absolutely nothing to increase the sound at any setting above 50%.  What you can hear sounds like a 20-year old laptop sitting on the floor of a school bathroom - tiny, echo-y, and very hard to understand.  I have several other monitors with built-in speakers, and these are by far the worst I have every heard.  The other monitor sitting next to this one sounds absolutely fantastic by comparison.  I have good speakers on my desk, but I was hoping to get rid of them to save some space - no way with this monitor!The picture quality seems decent - sitting side-by-side with a much older HP monitor of the same size and definition, both displays seem similar in brightness and color accuracy on an average browser window, but when comparing a screen with lots of high-contrast dark and light, this monitor is very washed out.  I have tried adjusting picture and color settings, and nothing improves the lack of a good black and poor contrast.  In fact, increasing the contrast setting just makes the blacks even MORE gray!But I am quite worried about the reliability.I set this up yesterday and left it on with the laptop in sleep mode all night - I didn't make any setting adjustments.  This morning the laptop woke fine and the monitor came on as expected, but as soon as I reached around the side of the monitor to find the control buttons, the monitor started flashing on and off, like a light with a loose or broken wire.  When I pulled my hand back, it was fine, but I could not touch the monitor at all without it flashing on and off.  The power light was not going on and off, so it was not that, and I tried changing the input to both HDMI ports with no difference.  Once I opened up the OSD, the flashing stopped as long as the OSD was up, but started again when I hit the Exit button.  After about 15 minutes of playing with the settings, I noticed that the monitor was no longer showing the problems when I touched it.  And it seems to still be working normally about an hour later.  But I am extremely worried about what was causing this issue, and how long it will be before it starts again.  If I wiggle the HDMI cable on the back of the monitor, it sometimes blanks out (but no where near as touchy  as it was in the beginning), so I guess the fault is there and I will have to return the unit.  What a pain.

reviewTitle: Budget 27" Monitor - Would be great if not for quality control issues
reviewDescription: This monitor is hard to love due to some glaring issues with its quality control. That being said, it's a budget conscious monitor that has a MSRP of $129.99 so you have to be realistic with your expectations. I'll go through my experience for you from start to finish.The Pros - It is 75hz refresh rate capable. 5ms response time for those who need it. It's light weight and very thin. (Great for mounting) It has 2 HDMI connectors. The version that I got uses a 12V DC port (Useful for cable management). Built in speakers a plus if you have limited space to work with. (Like using the monitor at a work station / terminal)The Cons - Out of 2 ordered, 1 had a dead pixel. The speakers are not only muffled, but extremely quiet. Stand is extremely light weight for a 27 inch monitor. 12V 3A AC/DC adapter looks really suspect (like the ones you get with LED strips) and probably will fail over time. VESA specs are incorrect in the manual. (They recommend M4 12mm screws). 1 year only warranty that requires you to send it back to them on your dime for service.My biggest gripe so far (dead pixel or not) is that the VESA mounting holes on the rear of the monitor are extremely shallow. I needed to special order a set of M4 8mm screws in order to get it to attach to one of my dual monitor brackets. VESA standards list 100 x 100 hole patterns to use a standard M4 10mm screw. My 8mm screws that I ordered barely fit into my bracket with a washer. I would assume the holes drilled in the monitor for the screws are 4mm or 5mm deep at best. The manual recommends using 12mm M4 screws! That would leave about 8mm or 7mm jutting out in the air. Most VESA mounting hardware will only include 10mm, 12mm and 25mm M4 screws for 100 x 100 hole patterns. So in case you want to mount this monitor to any bracket, make sure to have some shorter M4 screw sizes ready.Negatives aside, it's an extremely attractive monitor for the home office or the kids (teenager or college bound). You can forgive a lot of the imperfections if this is going to be attached to something you don't stare at constantly. Probably also good for grass roots e-sports tournament organizers who need a larger screen real estate but don't want to break the bank and aren't too worried about ultra quality. 5ms response time and 75hz refresh rate is good for most games except ultra competitive FPS.This is going to be a dynamic review in that I will update my experience as I own the monitor longer. I have a replacement coming from Amazon for the dead pixel afflicted one I got initially and we'll see how that goes. Sceptre's policy on dead pixels is that they need "5 or more" to be considered defective enough for warranty service. Worst yet, you have to ship the item back to them at your expense. So I highly recommend while you're in the Amazon 30 day return window to put the monitor through its paces and see if it's the right one for you without any major problems. Once it's out of that window, you'll be at the mercy of Sceptre's RMA department and will probably need to pay $22 bucks (or more) to send it back to fix a $129.99 (or less) monitor.

If you're looking for a cheap monitor that won't make your ears bleed, this might be a decent option. Just be prepared to wear earplugs and invest in some bright-colored paint.The best monitor parameters depend on your specific needs and preferences. However, here are some common parameters to consider when choosing a monitor:1. Screen size: The size of the monitor determines how much screen real estate you have to work with. Consider how much desk space you have and how much screen size you need to comfortably work.2. Resolution: The resolution of the monitor determines how sharp and clear the image is. Higher resolutions like 4K or 1440p offer sharper images, but also require more powerful hardware to run smoothly.3. Refresh rate: The refresh rate of a monitor determines how many times the screen updates per second. Higher refresh rates like 144Hz or 240Hz offer smoother motion and are preferred for gaming and other fast-paced activities.4. Response time: The response time of a monitor determines how quickly the pixels can change from one color to another. Lower response times like 1ms or 2ms are preferred for gaming and other fast-paced activities.5. Panel type: The panel type of a monitor determines the color accuracy, contrast, and viewing angles. There are three main types of panels: IPS, TN, and VA. IPS panels offer the best color accuracy and viewing angles, while TN panels offer the fastest response times. VA panels offer the best contrast.6. Connectivity: The connectivity options of a monitor determine what devices you can connect to it. Common connectivity options include HDMI, DisplayPort, and USB-C.7. Ergonomics: The ergonomics of a monitor determine how easily you can adjust its position. Consider features like adjustable height, tilt, and swivel to find a comfortable viewing angle.Overall, the best monitor parameters for you will depend on your specific needs and intended use.

reviewTitle: Great monitor but with a few annoying quirks.
reviewDescription: A quick word of advice to everyone who buys this monitor:  when you first hook it up to your computer, you will find that the screen (esp text, when scrolling) gets quite blurry and the colors might seem blotchy.  I was thinking that the monitor was defective when I saw it, but, after some homework, figured out that the problem is caused by faulty "overdrive" feature (or maybe not faulty?  never actually saw this feature before).  The control for "Overdrive" is under "System" and it's set to "medium" by default.  Turn it off.  Then the problem of blurry screen will go away and after that, the monitor is great.  (While I can't speak to the durability of this particular product, I've had generally excellent experience with Scepter monitors, all of which (I've had 4, including this one) were very durable over 3-4 years that I've used them.  At minimum, they products are worth it, IMHO.*Original review below:The short version is that the monitor is great (it is, fwiw, the most economical FHD monitor available), but some of the features don't seem to be working quite right.  One specific problem that came out right away was that the "Overdrive" feature is not working properly:  when you hook it up to your computer, you will find that objects on the monitor get blurry momentarily when you scroll.  After some searching, I found out that this is due to the overdrive feature that's supposed to speed up the response time...except, in this case, it's just making objects blurrier as they move with the mouse scroll.  The overdrive is set to "medium" in the factory setting.  You want to turn it off as the first thing you do.  After that, you should be happy.

reviewTitle: Screen going out after 15 months - do not recommend
reviewDescription: Initially purchased this as a cheap replacement for my dual monitor setup on my home work station. It’s decent and since I’m a developer, I just needed a display - nothing fancy. I liked the brand due to the brightness and colors so I had purchased another Sceptre 24”, going for the curved version. Since I was going to setup a new computer and desk in my son’s room, I was planning to give this flat panel to him for his PC and I’d purchase another curved monitor to match what I had on my desk. But earlier this month, I had to change those plans and look at alternatives, as this monitor started having issues after 15 months of use (bought in May 2022). I had still planned on buying the curved Sceptre 24” monitor to match my setup and placed an order for that. I also ordered a cheap 24” Philips VA monitor for my kid instead, since I couldn’t give him this monitor that was starting to act funky. This monitor would lose the display periodically while I was actively working on the screen. It became more frustrating when it would increase in frequency, especially during virtual meetings. Most recently, not only would the screen go out on me for a few seconds at a time (multiple times a day) but would start flickering and I’d also have dancing pixels and streams of red, blue, and greens dots in groups along the screen at times. My other external monitor and laptop screen was fine and I knew it wasn’t a graphics card issue.I know sometimes products wear out faster than others and initially wanted to review with 3 stars, but here’s the reason I’ll instead be lowering my rating. Since I was going to replace this monitor anyway, the panel malfunction made my purchasing decision more imminent. So I did order the Sceptre 24” curved monitor to replace this flat panel that was going out so I could get a nicer looking viewing angle for my dual monitor setup. When it was delivered, I tested it out and hooked it up to my workstation. I was only getting a black screen with vertical pixelated lines along the left portion of the panel. I checked my display settings and my laptop was detecting the monitor and I had it in the input source selection. When dragging my mouse over to where the new screen should have extended my display, the mouse cursor disappeared, so I knew it was picking up the display input perfectly fine, it just wasn’t displaying anything on the screen. Bottom line: it was defective out of the box. Packaging was not damaged in any way and my Ring cam showed my delivery driver handle it with care and gently placed it on the ground.  So I’ve gone through two back-to-back Sceptre brand monitors being defective. It’s probably my luck of the draw. I still have one working Sceptre monitor at the moment, but this will eventually be replaced, as I’m unsure of how long it will be operational for.So, for this product and this brand, I’d say it’s decent for a display, but don’t expect it to last a long time. It’s true that they say you get what you pay for at most times. This isn’t the exception, as much as I would have hoped it would be. While it can serve as a decent budget monitor, keep in mind that it may not live up to the longevity of other more pricier well-known and higher quality manufacturers. Ultimately, I do not recommend this product in the long run. I will not buy from this brand again. Please do some research and invest in better quality and more well-known manufacturers. I’ll also be rating the other Sceptre 24” curved monitor as well.

Ordered two of these.One monitor powered up and would only display snow. What is this, an 80s TV set? Returned for refund. (I originally planned to exchange it, but also discovered my work-issued laptop doesn't support two external monitors, and I didn’t need a replacement monitor elsewhere in the house).The second one works…kinda. It blanks out all the time, often during Zoom meetings when I'm screen sharing and demonstrating something. It usually comes back on within few seconds, though. It’s pretty random, and I can’t create a set of circumstances that will trigger it.Thought it was the connector. All my HDMi cables have fat plastic grips around the connectors, too thick to plug straight into the monitor without the connector coming out at  slight angle. Got a 90-degree HDMI adaptor. Improved somewhat, but didn’t really fix it.Thought maybe my USB-C dock wasn’t pushing enough power to HDMI, even though it never had a problem with other (admittedly smaller) monitors. Replaced it with another dock. That seemed to work, right until it didn’t.I’ve come to the conclusion that Scepter is nice and cheap, and you get what you pay for.Caveat emptor.

reviewTitle: TERRIBLE MONITOR, AVOID AT ALL COSTS!!!
reviewDescription: I recently purchased this Sceptre monitor, and I must say it has been an absolute nightmare. I expected a reliable display that would last me for years, but unfortunately, it barely made it through a single month of use before showing serious issues. I am extremely disappointed with the quality and the abysmal customer service I encountered.After just a few weeks, green lines began appearing on the screen, distorting the visuals and making it impossible to use the monitor properly. This defect severely impacted my work and entertainment experience. It's astonishing that a product could fail so quickly.When I contacted Sceptre customer service in the hopes of getting a replacement, I was met with nothing but frustration. Their lackluster response left me feeling utterly dissatisfied. Instead of acknowledging the faulty unit, they insisted on repairing it, which would have been a hassle in itself. But the worst part is that they expected me to cover the shipping and insurance fees for the defective product. This is unacceptable!The manufacturer's refusal to take responsibility for their faulty product and their insistence on charging the customer for their own mistakes speaks volumes about their poor customer service. It's evident that they prioritize profits over customer satisfaction. This experience has left a bitter taste in my mouth, and I strongly advise anyone considering purchasing a monitor to look elsewhere.Save yourself the frustration, disappointment, and wasted money by exploring other reputable brands that prioritize their customers' needs and provide reliable products. Don't make the same mistake I did by investing in this subpar monitor from Sceptre. There are far better options available in the market that offer superior quality, durability, and customer support.Luckily, Amazon has stellar customer service.  They stepped in and helped me get my money back.

reviewTitle: Be careful with this monitor and this company -  lasted 2 months. Repair service dubious
reviewDescription: Bought 2 of these monitors in April. One started acting up end of May. Too late to return so called Amazon who put me in touch with Sceptre. First call it's like the tech support guy didn't believe me. Told me I had to try it with different cables and on different computers. Did that and got back to them, questions again about did I do this and that. Convinced him I had so sent to web site to fill out an RMA request that needed to be sent in along with the pictures I took of the monitor. Told me the RMA would take 3 to 4 days to get processed and approved. Then have to ship it back on our dime and it would take about 3 weeks to fix it. In the mean time my boss has to use some other monitor.Most companies I deal with replace defective equipment and send a return shipping label for the old part. If you don't ship it back you get charged for it. But this company thinks it's OK to make you return their defective product on your dime and leave you without equipment for a month while they decide if they will fix it.Well they finally decided it was the monitor and not the PC or cables and had me send it in to be repaired. They did send me a box to return it in and did pay for shipping both ways. However after several weeks and getting the monitor back,I put is on a brand new PC and tried it with both a VGA cable and an HDMI cable and it is doing the same thing I sent it in for. When windows puts the monitor to sleep, when it powers back up it is unusable as the picture shows.Right now waiting to see what they are going to do.Got an email this morning asking me to try a few things. It still isn't right. Some companies don't know when to cut their losses. They have probably spent more on shipping, repairs and time then it's worth not to mention customer satisfaction and goodwill.

I had this monitor for about 6 months before the screen just stopped working. I reached out to customer support via phone, we went through the troubleshooting process and confirmed it was a defective monitor and to email for a warranty claim.Once I emailed they made me go through the exact same process, and actually tried to suggest I installed the monitor incorrectly at first. After several emails, they finally said they’d replace the monitor.Their warranty replacement is different than most vendors. They require you to send their device back first. It took about two weeks for them to send me a box to ship the clearly broken monitor back. The first box they sent me was apparently lost by fedex, which just caused additional delays.I had to ask them three separate times to provide the return label. Why didn’t they just provide that in the box they sent me? Who knows.Once they finally received the monitor, I had to follow up with them AGAIN to ship out the new monitor.FedEx delivered the monitor to the wrong address. The support team currently is not providing any updates or resolutions to the issue.It’s been about two months since their monitor stopped working, and I still have no resolution. While I understand part of the challenge was with fedex, they’re the ones who chose to use them, and they are the ones who need to fix this.The experience with the support staff has been awful. They are slow to respond and make you jump through hoops to get anything done. I bought two monitors, one was faulty. So a 50% failure rate from my experience and terrible customer support. You get what you pay for.I have bought and used 4-5 Asus monitors. While they’re a little more expensive, I never had a single issue. I regret going with the cheapest option.

I went into Nvidia settings. There is absolutely no 75 Hz refresh rate option and it doesn’t matter what I do to try and get one to pop up. I am using the same type and brand HDMI cable that is giving 140+ Hz refresh rate on the other monitor I bought at the same time.This is a false claim on the part of the seller and I’m very much not happy about this. False claims get 1 star (because it turns on and displays an image).I don’t like being lied to or misled about a product. Especially one that costs $99+.Secondly, the monitor has a bracket that does not come off. Makes it difficult if not impossible (time will tell) to mount the unit in a safe way using a VESA bracket. Do not buy this monitor if you plan to mount it. I’m now going to have to invest more money in a safer/better monitor. Again, I am not happy with this purchase but I can’t afford the downtime it will take to return it.Update: immediately after I posted the review, I edited it, but I guess the edit didn’t go through. I forgot to use the metal standoff screws that they included in the package when I first tried to put the bracket on. Without the metal stand off screws, it will be too short to fit over the bracket. With the metal stand off screws, it clears the bracket. This was a mistake was fixed almost immediately on my part before it even got mounted. That was a me error not a sceptre error.That said, the product still gets only one star for the seller lying about specs.

reviewTitle: Won't turn on. Only had 5 weeks
reviewDescription: TDRL: Spend a few more dollars to get something thats not junk.Set the monitor up for my wife so she could play pc games with me. Did not come with a power supply and had to order a compatible one. We went on vacation around the time that it came in so its only been in use for about 3 weeks due to being away then finding out it had now power source.Died while we were in the middle of playing a game. Attempted to troubleshoot to no avail.

reviewTitle: Poor quality stand - do not recommend
reviewDescription: The monitor is just all right, but it is  cheap, so don't expect much.  The stand system is made of the poor quality plastic. It broke very quickly. Being unable to find the replacement on line, I called, emailed and texted Sceptre office multiple times, sent photos of the part I need. No response.  Horrible customer service.  They tell you to email them, then when you do, no response! The monitor is useless without the stand, so I am forced to buy another monitor although this one works fine.

Would have been a great buy - with nice features like built in speakers, which would seem OK forZOOM, and I did not expect better quality like for music.  But, the screen flickered out of the box. Tried all the usual fixes, including different cables, various refresh rates and settings, different computers. All to no avail.  Had no choice but to give one-star on the product.  Amazon Support was truly outstanding to authorize the return--instantly. Bought an Acer instead.  So far, I love it even more--albeit it's been only 2-days--than if the Sceptre had functioned properly. If you get a good Sceptre E275W-19203R, this would be a super good buy for the price.

With all of the favorable reviews I saw regarding this monitor, I apparently got a lemon. This monitor has been defective for about 3 months now and I regret buying the cheaper product. It worked great for about 8 months and then crashed. Sorry Sceptre, but I will never trust your product line again. I'll pay the extra $$$ and get something that will last and that I can trust. Cheers!

reviewTitle: DONT BUY IT FOR THE SPEAKERS
reviewDescription: If you happen to be like me and wanted to get a decent screen with decent speakers, this is not your product. I have bought it and used it much to my chagrin with utterly dismal brightness and as good as sound quality as a 1992 honda civic (not suped up)... Ultimately I'm returning it because it was not what I need or want and as a word of caution to whoever else is looking for similar qualities. I'm guessing a little more bucks gets a better product.

I bought this because of the good reviews, size, and its claim to have speakers included. The image quality is decent, it's light and thin, and it does have speakers. But the speaks are absolutely HORRIBLE sounding. When I was a kid my grandmother had a little portable radio she used to carry from room room, in her hand, when she did her housecleaning. THAT little transistor radio had better and louder sound quality than this!  RETURNED. I don't want to have to have more wires, equipment, etc around for audio. In this day and age they should be able to install a decent set of speakers in this thing without much additional cost. I would rather pay a little more to get a complete package that I can look at from more than 4 feet away and actually HEAR the sound.

Works as a monitor ok, but even after upgrading my Nvidia drivers and trying everything I could find, I cannot even hear people speaking on a youtube video with sound at 100% in Windows and on the Monitor.I wanted this because my speakers in my laptop that we are now using as a desktop computer are blown and I did not want anything else powered that I'd have to plug in.. At this point the blown laptop speakers are louder than the monitor speakers which are in our face!I do NOT recommend this monitor.

reviewTitle: Bunch of Lines on Monitor after 13 Months
reviewDescription: Worked and looked great for about a year. Right after warranty expired, lines appeared on bottom third of screen. Now there are about a dozen lines after 15 months of use. Seller will repair but I have to pay for shipping.

Monitor was great for the first year and then 3 days after the 1 year mark, purple line appears across monitor.  Now within the last month, 2 more lines appeared.  Monitor did not last like I expected it.

reviewTitle: Don't waste your money on this cut rate garbage.
reviewDescription: I purchased mine in April and I hate it. The stand is flimsy an most definitely not the one that is shown on the images. Any slight movement and the whole thing wobbles like the stand is about to break in two. It promises 75hz but with only 1 working HDMI out of two, it's not looking like that'll be true ever. For as bright as it is, the colors look washed out and terrible, and I had a stuck pixel from day 1 but thankfully giving it a soft whack fixed it...until it happened again. What adds insult to injury is that my HP 27" from 3 years ago has better picture quality than this. What a fool I was.Over all, get something else. Don't be a sucker like me. I wish I could get a refund on this but I needed it for work and money was tight.

reviewTitle: It's Fine. Should Be $50. Worst Viewing Angle I Have Ever Seen.
reviewDescription: The monitor looks quite nice with thin bezels and overall thin and lightweight build. The image quality is not very good although it does get pretty bright. I use with a Mac and when Night Shift is turned on and you enter full screen mode on the monitor the screen auto turns on it's warmest setting, so it turns orange. Seems to work normally when not in fullscreen viewing. The worst part about the monitor is the viewing angle. Unless you are looking directly in the center and it is set perfectly to eye level it is unusable. Even turning your head to look at the edges shifts the colors and brightness. Overall it is way overpriced for what you get. Might be ok for basic productivity but not good for gaming or media consumption.

The first thing that I notice when turning this monitor on is how faded the colors look.  Even after calibrating the colors on my operating system, it just looks like the monitor has been left on for about 10 years.  Definitely not a monitor I would use for gaming if that is your thing.  I want to use it for video editing, and I definitely would not use it for that.  It has a good size and it's light weight.  The price is good, but the picture quality is definitely lacking.

I bought two monitors, but I couldn't get two of the same so I bought this. As soon as I got it I could see the flicker issue. Most of the time it's OK, but it shouldn't do that at all. The other thing was that the color seemed dull next to my other monitor and I couldn't get it any better through adjustments. I suspect I never would have noticed it if it wasn't right next to my other similar priced monitor from a major computer maker that had more vibrant colors and no flickers and just made this one look bad.  I found that the other monitors are now in stock so I returned this and got another one of those..

reviewTitle: Less than two years is dies
reviewDescription: I got this because I needed home monitors for work. and here it is two years later and it is dead. I have Asus monitors that are 4 years old and still going strong. Now I am down a monitor and with the shortage no way to get a new one. Stay away from this company they do not build anything to last..

Function seems fine, however due to the size & orientation the plug & power supply will effectively block 4 outlets on a standard surge protector strip. I had to purchase a new one with side facing outlets. Probably not a big deal, but still frustrating.

Found this great size monitor for Work needs, I'm no gamer so refresh rates and all didn't matter to me. simple setup and had two HDMI ports which was great and rare to find at this price. overall I'm satisfied and it does its job. Great quality.

I got this on a good price on here, as it filled a couple specific needs I had. I'm using this on a boat running navigation  software on a Raspberry Pi 4. For that purpose, it should work well. Screen has good clarity and does get rather bright when set. Including standoffs for vesa mounts to clear the stand mount is a nice addition. The speakers are a joke for anything but a very quiet home-desk where you're sitting less than 5' from it. They aren't very full sounding, and even at max volume they get drowned out by any background noise. Luckily having an audio out jack helps with this. The only other thing I would've liked to see though would be a remote to adjust the settings instead of having to reach around to the back. Until you have a feel for them, or keep the manual handy, you have to fumble a little to get through the menu. Even just a basic menu-up-down-enter remote would've been good.For the price, it's a decent 1080 monitor, very lightweight, and multiple inputs is great. If you want to use it for more than a monitor, add a cheap set of speakers and it'll do better. If you get a good sale on it, it just makes it better.

The monitor is great!  Clear picture.  Works well.  My only frustration is that it looks in the picture and is described as a tilting monitor.  It is not.  It's stationary.  I was in a bind and needed to have it, so found another solution to its downward tilt.  Aside from that, good monitor.

Good quality picture, easy to access controls and inputs. The speaker's sound is harsh like it comes from inside a tin can. A  better-sounding speaker could make this monitor an excellent buy for the price, and a possible five stars overall rating.

reviewTitle: Crisp, bright display with tinny speakers
reviewDescription: Bought this monitor to put alongside my Sceptre E248W-1920R for a dual monitor setup. These were both quite lightweight and fit my dual monitor VESA mounts just fine. I got this model right on time for delivery and have been testing it out for its intended use in a home office setup. Been quite happy so far, so here is a review in light of having both of these models.Pros:1) Lightweight and has 4 VESA mounting screws, which make it perfect for fitting in dual monitor arm setups.2) Excellent and bright display which handles displaying online meeting video, training videos, and coding just fine.3) The price for value is pretty great, looking at alternatives for this size.Only cons here are:1) The sound is quite tinny, which is hinted at in the description as "office level audio".2) There is no remote, so any audio adjustments will be done awkwardly using the buttons behind the monitor for my setup. Tune it using your computer instead.3) Minor complaint, the frame of the monitor is plastic. I'm happier about the other model with its metal frame, which is magnetic.4) Again, minor: certain visual settings can only be accessed by choosing a "custom" video mode to access brightness, contrast, etc.

These are not meant to be top of the line. But for the price they are pretty d*** good.If youre on a budget its the way to go. However there are some acer ones that are $119 so IF you can swing up to that range, then there you go. If not, then welcome to the sceptre club.After plugging an xbox series s in and playing some cod and watching a few videos on them. They’re pretty crispy for the price.Happy gaming yall! 4.5 stars

reviewTitle: I liked my first one so much that I bought a second one
reviewDescription: I use this monitor on a daily basis as a work from home employee and find that it's the "best bang for the buck".  I had bought one over a year ago and believed it to be a good enough monitor to buy a second one to replace my other aged monitor.  The picture quality is good enough for my job functions which includes reading/observing on dark and light backgrounds.  However, at times some text on webpages look fuzzy when they are at 8 point or lower.

Next time I would appreciate if the product was put in a box or something. I live in an apartment and it was left at my door like this all day. Not completely sure if this is a problem for the seller or the post office but someone could’ve seen this and stolen it. Regarding the actual product I’m Overall satisfied with its performance. Perfect for doing office work and light gaming. Playing Apex Legends on it with no problems

reviewTitle: Washed-out Colors, but OK for the Price
reviewDescription: My only real issue with this monitor (not a reason to return it) is that the colors seem to be a bit washed out compared to other monitors. But, at this price point, that is to be expected. I have ordered a different brand replacement, so at this time I am waiting for it to arrive.NOTE: I thought that the monitor had an issue where it would periodically "blink", but I have my wife now trying it in a different room to see if it is the monitor or the power to one of my outlets. I will update this review if the blinking continues. I was planning on returning the monitor because of this, but may end up letting her use it if the blinking is not the fault of the monitor.
monitor stopped working on novembere 3,2023. deleivered on september 22, 2023. no power no anything. garbage. also no reponse from manufacturer. DO NOT BUY

Bought these Monitors 1 month ago. For a whole month sat in the box until I received my other parts.(deal was good and was going in and out of stock)Been waiting for specific legs & Plexi-glass to come in for my custom desk.I finished my desk build and put both of these monitors up on my Mount.Behold 2 dead pixels right out the box, from a gaming standpoint there's nothing worse.Bleeding on the blacks and whites, by far terrible.The quality of the pictures is terrible too.I don't want to be too biased but for $50 - $60 more you're guaranteed a good monitor, with a higher refresh rate and better branding.If you're gonna use this monitor for gaming don't buy it.If you're gonna use it purely for watching youtube videos from a 5-10 ft distance this is the monitor for you.

VERY bad product and horrible customer service. The monitor lasted barely 3 months being used simply for word processing a few hours a week. Started with flickering, then went totally black except for some random lines. Next day it turned on, then 10 minutes into turning it on, it abruptly turned off and will not turn back on. Customer service is nonexistant. Pointing me all over the place and resolving nothing. PLUS they make it clear in their FAQ that they'll want ME to pay shipping on their dead product. Shameful.Amazon needs to rectify this situation since Sceptre clearly won't. I shouldn't be out of the money and a monitor in only 3 months.Update: over a week after contacting Sceptre's support and I STILL do not have any idea what's happening with repair/replacement/refund. Amazon themselves are not assisting, nor is my credit card protection plan because they need information from Sceptre who is not responding to any emails/calls.

Bought this as a second monitor. I work mostly in Word on this monitor (a mostly white background) and slowly these lines have appeared. First it was 1, then 2, and now 1/3rd of the screen is covered in them. This began around the 6 month mark and now, 1 year and 1 week after purchasing, the monitor is inoperable. The worst part is their warranty requires you to ship the monitor (at your expense) to California and then they can deem if they will send you a new one or not.

reviewTitle: Amazon shipping E279, Not E275 , terrible quality
reviewDescription: Originally I purchased the E275, The contrast and brightness and color were all very good. I decided to go with a two monitor set up so I ordered the same monitor. However the newer model is terrible, no matter what you do with the settings it has a yellow dull tint it’s really bad. So On their website they continue to refer to it as the E275, But when you open the box it will actually say E279, I would return it immediately.  And working with Amazon they say it is impossible for them to know what is actually in the box so they will continue to ship the wrong part number, or to them it is the same part number but with substandard components used in manufacturing. Stay away
broke easily when I punched it at maximum velocity

reviewTitle: Worked for 30 days and now won't turn on
reviewDescription: I purchased 3 of these monitors in April 2021, and now in July 2021, and one of the monitors does not turn on.  When it was on right before it stopped working, I went to shut it off and it would not turn off.  The light stays red to show it is in off mode, and it will not turn on (blue light).  I tried all the fixes on the internet and still nothing.  Seems like others have had this problem.  So, figure you are going to spend money on a monitor that works for 2 months, and then it will become unless.  I am going to buy a dell like I should have in the beginning.It's a pain to have to redo my whole setup because of one monitor.  Not to mention extra costs I did not plan on.

I purchased this monitor and was surprised that the listing did not display "open box" cause this monitor was definitly not new. The box had a sticker from another address that had been mostly ripped off the cardboard. There were loose screews at the bottom of the box (not in a sealed plastic) for the base of the monitor. The monitor had obvious smudges and liquid stains or spills that had been on the screen for a while. Lastly, the monitor did not come with a power cord so I can't plug it in to the wall. I understand the monitor's don't always come with a cable to connect to the computer but this one didn't even have a cable to connect to the wall.If they are going to sell a monitor like this, they should at least mention it is an open box item and not try to sell it as a new item.
My monitor died in August, 2023, so not a long lived product.Also, lousy audio.  (Ok, maybe my tech ignorance.)I bought the monitor in October 2022.

reviewTitle: Monitor does not work after 4 months
reviewDescription: Have other monitors by Sceptre and they have worked fine for the most part. I bought this on January 1st 2023 and it does not work with any computers I have at my house after 5 months of owning it. It turns on but will not register any HDMI connected to it as a valid input. Spend the extra $20 a get a nicer brand
Didn’t work!  Came on once or twice but wouldn’t work as it should.

We bought 3. With in a year they started forming lines at the bottom and losing color. This one pictured I use for home school and it's so bad now I'll need to replace it soon. All 3 have starting losing their picture at the bottom but this one is the worst.

reviewTitle: Both monitors stopped working after 1 year
reviewDescription: I bought 2 of these computer monitors 1 year ago (I know this because that is when I started my job). I work from home so I used both everyday until suddenly they stopped working within an hour of each other. Would NOT have spent the money if I knew it was only going to last a year. Was not worth it and certainly wasn’t an investment I should have made.
Picture quality is so low and discolored/distorted even after adjustment it is not worth the money. Spend a few bucks more, this is a complete waste.
The screen had four lines on it. I had to send it back.
how in the halibut is an unsealed package missing the most important piece to put it together?!?!? money can't buy anything of quality these days

Great picture quality. I liked that the monitor had built in speakers. The volume is so low and can't be adjusted. Called company and was advised it's a known flaw and obviously the company chooses not to do anything about it.
Monitor has a lot of issues. I had to remove and plug in the hdmi cable every time I use for the monitor to recognize the signal. It’s not worth the money. I wish I had returned it long back.

I bought this a little over a year ago - very limited use with my surface pro.  No gaming.  Work related.  When I turn it on - the above photo happens in a minute or less.  Googled and followed all suggested steps to correct - including updating driver.  Nothing worked.
It worked mostly okay for 3 months. Mostly. And then today, boom, it no longer turns on. The computer recognizes it is plugged in.
As advertised
Good quality - just what I needed for my home office! Would buy again!

reviewTitle: I bought this because of failing eyesight and the size improved my ability to read the screen
reviewDescription: I thought the  cost was reasonable and it was easy to install.

reviewTitle: Great budget monitor - great for rejuvenating an old PC
reviewDescription: I recently resurrected an 11 year old Lenovo desktop PC.  While it's old and originally came with Windows 7, with an upgrade to Windows 10 and the replacement of the boot drive with an SSD, it really runs fast for it's age.  So, I treated it to a new monitor, and I chose this one.  The price was under $100 and I didn't expect much, but was surprised how good it looks externally, and how good the picture looks.  The audio is pretty weak, but good enough to hear windows sounds and listen to YouTube videos.  It's pretty bad on music.  However, I use a small Oontz Angle speaker wired to the audio output of this Sceptre and it's acceptable listening even with music.  Acceptable, but not great.  Having the HDMI bring the audio to the monitor makes the wiring of the Oontz neat.  So, if you're looking for a good quality budget monitor, I recommend this one.
I wanted a monitor with speakers and this one fit the bill. The audio quality is somewhat low though and colours tend to distort when viewed from side angles.
Good quality screen, sleek, easy setup…. Yeah sound quality is the same as any computer screen since the 90’s. Good for doing multi screen work.
Have had a pair of these 24” monitors for 3.5 years, use for work daily. No dead pixels, work great, no quality issues

reviewTitle: a very great monitor very thin and light weight
reviewDescription: sceptre 24 inch monitor has a great quality and works very well the picture is sharp and is easy to set up and is a great quality

reviewTitle: Great price for this quality monitor
reviewDescription: My son was looking for a new monitor to use for gaming with his PS5. After reading several reviews, we decided on this one. He is very pleased with the resolution and features of this model, while I was very pleased with the price.

reviewTitle: Old laptop screen died - needed a new monitor
reviewDescription: So, thankfully my old Toshiba 17" laptop didn't completely die. To replace it would cost $1500+ (I get higher end laptops). It has a HDMI (v1) monitor output. SO, I bought this Sceptre 100 Hz 24" LED monitor to use with the laptop.THE GOOD- fast delivery- lightweight- Beautiful colors and lots of picture adjustments to find your sweet spot- movies, videos, fast action anything is top notch- price- out of the box set up ease and auto-detects your PC sourceTHE SO-SO- longevity?- is 100 Hz really that much better than 75 Hz when using a HDMI (v1) with 60 Hz. Worth the price bump?- speakers suck - use Bluetooth or the 3.5mm audio out (which works fine on this monitor)- within two feet of viewing, not the best. At about 30-32" away excellentBOTTOM LINE- Excellent monitor for $99. No eye fatigue. Lots of presentation adjustments. Colors look true. Easy to unbox and get back to gaming/work

Likes: Price, Solid build quality....not wobbly.  Both PC and MAC recognized brand and model right away.  HDMI cable included but I used mine anyway.  Very good formed solid foam packaging. Overall value for the money.Cons:  No tilt, swivel, etc.  First impression of picture quality on my MAC air was OK....  But I'm guessing overnight it adjusted drivers as in the morning the picture was crisp and clean.  The opening background on the MAC where it moves across the screen looked almost 3D.  Very impressive.  Overall it is a very acceptable screen for the cost.  I would go bigger if I was a gamer of course, but more importantly, I would give Sceptre brand a look.  Durability is yet to be determined.

reviewTitle: It comes with speakers but the sound quality is poor.
reviewDescription: The picture quality is great. The sound quality is very poor. No volume and it sounds like it's coming from a tin can. Order a sound bar!
It’s a pretty decent screen and does its job. Mainly it’s should be used for pc because Xbox and other consoles struggled if you plug in devices but overall works

I've only had the monitor for a day but I'm happy with the purchase. I initially tried to cancel the order but the seller had already shipped. I figured I would give it a try and send it back if it wasn't up to spec. I'm coming from a 12 year old Samsung T260HD monitor that is 25.5 inches, 1920x1200 @60hz. This was top of the line at the time and paid $329 while this was one was only $109. The old monitor had screen tearing in games (no g-sync or freesync) and FPS play wasn't ideal, especially in COD Warzone. If you've never played on a higher refresh rate monitor before, it makes a difference. I tried overclocking the monitor to 85hz and then 80hz but neither took so I tried out the rated spec of 75hz with freesync and let me say.. I could notice the difference right away and even picked up my first Warzone Solo victory. Aiming was much more smooth and I could keep my reticle glued on other players. If you're using this for light gaming and you're coming from a 60hz panel, you'll be pleasantly surprised. This appears to be a TN panel because the viewing angles are poor. They're completely fine when viewed straight ahead - since this is being used as a computer monitor, it's not a problem for me but buyer beware. No dead pixels or edge bleeding to speak of. Blacks aren't super dark but decent and the factory setting was ok as far as brightness and contrast was concerned. I configured to my liking and I'm satisfied. The stand is wobbly as others have stated and I didn't even bother with speakers, nor should you. I'm not expecting this thing to last but I'm hoping to get 2-3 years out of it. I was looking to get a higher refresh rate monitor (144-165hz) but after doing research, you can't take advantage of the higher refresh rate unless your frames per second average is just as high (144+fps). With a Ryzen 5 2600 and an aging Rx 570, I'm getting an average of 75fps in COD Warzone with the settings at high. In this case, the monitor is a perfect pairing for the 75hz refresh rate.In order to take advantage of the higher refresh rate you will need to open up your AMD or Nvidia software and create a profile that is set @75hz. Once this is created, go into display settings on your computer -> advanced settings -> monitor and then select the new 75hz profile from the drop down. Last, you will need to enable freesync from the monitor control panel (it's in the menu options) and then enable it in the AMD software (not sure about Nvidia). If you're lucky, you may be able to overclock the monitor to a higher refresh rate. Just create a profile for 80 or 85hz, select it in display settings and see if it takes. If it doesn't, the monitor will revert back to the previous refresh rate in 10 seconds. From what I've read, this doesn't harm your monitor and it depends on the manufacturer as to how far you can overclock it. Don't expect much from this panel, however. All-in-all, it's an upgrade for me in just about every way. Some people say a 27" screen at 1080p for gaming isn't ideal. I beg to differ. The pixel density isn't superb by any means but I didn't notice any difference from a slightly smaller screen (25.5 vs 27) and less pixels (old monitor was 1920x1200). If I had to choose, I'd take the extra real-estate over pixel density which I think only amounts to 6ppi. There's pixel density calculators out there if you're curious. If you can afford it and your GPU/CPU can achieve 100+fps, I would go with a higher refresh rate monitor. For lower end specs, general use or a second monitor and for the low price, I don't see why not.

reviewTitle: Great for productivity, perhaps not for gaming or media creation and consumption
reviewDescription: Well, the old adage, "You get what you pay for", holds true in this case.Physical Appearance------------------------The monitor looks nice, with thin bezels and a simple raised, "metallic" sceptre logo at the bottom bezel. The stand is nothing to write home about, and only features tilt adjustment, not height adjustment. The monitor is surprisingly thin for this price point, and would be great VESA mounted, but I'm using the included stand.One thing I noticed is the sturdiness of the stand. My desk has some wiggle in it, and when typing I can visibly notice the monitor wiggle back and forth a bit, which can be annoying.Performance----------------This is where things go down hill. Rather than belabor these points, I'll bulletize:- Very noticeable backlight bleeding around the corners. I work in an IDE (i.e. fancy programming text editor) that uses a dark theme, so the backlight bleeding is very noticeable with the dark background- Washed out colors. Just general lack of vibrancy in the colors and muted overall- Color accuracy? visually, based on how washed out the colors are; I'm going to wager the color accuracy is not good. NOTE: I haven't measured, but let's be real here.- Speakers. It has builtin speakers. They work. That's about the best compliment I can give them. Use headphones.Overall Opinion--------------------I personally got this monitor for my home office. I work as a software engineer and work from home frequently. This is my second monitor, alongside my 5+ year old 900p Gateway TFT LCD monitor.First off, my old monitor performs better in all the above mentioned short comings. Vibrant color and no visible backlight bleeding. I don't know how much the gateway monitor cost originally, as I got it from an old neighbor who was moving out :)So, even compared to monitors of years gone by, this thing is underwhelming.That all said, for productivity use, I can't complain that much. The muted nature actually seems to reduce eye strain perhaps. As we say in the software world, "It's not a bug, it's a feature!". The backlight bleed, while annoying, is easily forgotten once I'm actually focused working on something. Color accuracy and vibrancy doesn't matter to me. My general use case is: programming, IM, email, documentation writing/reading, web browsing, and general productivity usage.Conclusion-------------At the end of the day, it's a 24" 1080p monitor for just shy of $100. If you're planning on using it for gaming, photo/video editing, general media consumption, or anything in that area; I'd suggest spending a bit more for a better monitor.On the other hand, if you just want something for general office/productivity usage. I mean, it's under $100 and it works. So I'd definitely recommend it for that use case.

reviewTitle: Excellent monitor, but don't plan to hang it on the wall
reviewDescription: I had a good experience with a smaller Sceptre, and love the fact that there are two HDMI inputs. This is a great budget 1080p monitor. I use this as a secondary monitor to help with multi-tasking and also have my PS4 connected to it. There are obvious pros and cons to this monitor, but keep the price in mind.Pros:Matte finish to help against glarePlenty of options to adjust pictureBlue light shift has multiple levels of adjustment to make picture warmer if desiredVESA mountableBuilt in speakersPriceCons:Speaker output qualityLED indicator (subjective)For an IPS panel (stated by vendor in questions section) this doesn't have the greatest viewing anglesThe included stand is a bit wobblyAll ports face downward (subjective)The Pros of the monitor are pretty self explanatory so I'll go over the cons.-Although advertised as a 75 Hz monitor, it's running at 60Hz in 1080p. But this could possibly be due to the cheaper hdmi cable I got for this monitor.-The speakers don't have the greatest sound quality, but I didn't expect much for the price. The speakers work fine if you just want to hear something from your game, but I don't recommend them as primary audio output.-There is an LED indicator on the bottom right corner (LED projects light downward) that illuminates solid blue when it receives signal, blinks blue when it's awake and awaiting signal, and is solid red when the monitor is off/asleep.-Like mentioned above, the vendor answered a question about the panel and stated it's an IPS panel. I also have an LG 27GL83A-B IPS monitor and the viewing angles are much better than the spectre. But again, keep the price in mind.-The included stand is a bit wobbly but I ended up mounting this monitor so I stored the stand. This monitor did not include hardware to VESA mount so ensure the monitor mount/stand has hardware or get hardware.-The power, HDMI, and VGA port face downwards so you may need 90 degree adapters for the HDMI ports to prevent the cables from sticking out from the bottom of the monitor.-Something else noting is the buttons on my monitor are in a horizontal orientation, but still in the bottom right corner.OVERALL: I researched a bit before deciding on this monitor and I'm very happy with my purchase. I've already recommended this monitor to other friends looking for a budget friendly 27" monitor and if I had to do it over again I'd still stick with this monitor.

reviewTitle: Pretty good for general use although I wouldn't exactly rave about them
reviewDescription: I purchased two of these monitors for a dual display home office setup and they function similarly. Black levels are poor, picture quality is acceptable and backlighting is shockingly very even. The led backlighting either isn't zoned or at least doesn't strike me as zoned (I don't remember whether or not this was advertised as zoned but I suspect it wasn't). With all that said, I didn't expect these to be amazing monitors. As general purpose 24" budget displays these are pretty good. I haven't used them to game so I can't attest to the sync on the 75hz mode.I purchased these for a home office setup where I'm looking at emails, spreadsheets, command shells and web browsers all day peppered with the odd VTC call. These do those tasks admirably. I'm sitting 34-44 inches away from these screens 10-12 hours a day and my eyes haven't started to feel any strain so that's a plus.Build quality on one of them is displaying (ha pun not intended) a bit of bezel separation. I only noticed this about 2 weeks into ownership but it isn't enough for me to go through the hassle of unmounting it from my monitor arm and swapping it out if an RMA were approved, but it is enough for me to drop a star.I will also note that there is no real re-enforcement to this chasis. When mounted to an adjustable monitor arm I would recommend only rotating,swinging or pivoting by grabbing opposing bezel corners rather than opposing bezel edge as otherwise you will introduce a bit of flex.  This is something I always check when mounting new monitors for the first time and holy heck did these not even pass my minimum comfort zone for rigidity on even the lightest adjustment when going by the edges - corners only for sure.Other than the bezel separation these panels hit my expectations for a inexpensive general purpose 24" displays with dual HDMI inputs. I haven't performed any calibration on these displays so my "acceptable" rating on their picture quality could potentially be improved upon and I've used preconfigured picture settings.

reviewTitle: Great Gaming Monitor, But if you need a portrait monitor or not technically savvy be warned.
reviewDescription: This is a great lightweight monitor with a reasonably light screen.  I have since replaced it with the 32 inch widescreen monitor and decided to replace my old portrait monitor with this.  Seeing that it has the mounting appropriate for a 3rd party desk mount chose to remove the existing stand and mount it onto my desk mount.The existing mount hardware is impossible to remove without opening the entire monitor to access the internal mounting hardware.  This was not hard but can be intimidating and must be done with care not to snap the monitor faceplate.  Once the back was separated from the front, I needed a small wrench to remove the nuts from the pivot pins for the internal mountain bracket.  This was not simple and required extreme care not to damage the ports and electronics next to the pins.After removing the internal mounting hardware, was able to secure the back and faceplate.  Then I was able to mount the monitor to my existing stand.  Note I lost one HDMI port as the port is precariously close to where the mounting plate fits, covering half the second HDMI port.  This was not a problem as I use the monitor with a single HDMI input.The monitor now works perfectly as a portrait monitor for reading documents.

reviewTitle: I am extremelly impressed with this monitor! Great buy specially for gaming!
reviewDescription: I have a GTX 1060 laptop, set up is easy and there was no need for me to calibrate anything, I even dare say this monitor looks better than my own laptop screen at 1080p.At first i thought it didn not support 75Hz and the colors were washed out and it was too bright, also on the nvidia panel it said 1080p at 60Hz however this is what you gotta do to fix it."CALIBRATION"1. Connect via HDMI2. Open Display settings and make sure that they are set so that only the 2nd display is turned on, do not put duplicate or extend.3. Open Nvidia control panel and go to "Change Resolution"4. You will see two lists, one will say HD, UHD etc, the other one at the bottom will say "PC", (changing the first list will project your laptop screen to the second screen however your laptop is 60Hz and the monitor is 75Hz that is why its limited to 60Hz and colors are washed out, changing the second list will basically use your laptop to power up the monitor at full 75Hz 1080p with the right color calibration.)5. On list two "PC" change the resolution to 1080p and 75HzAnd there you go, now you can use your 75Hz monitor for gaming, make sure to change the settings indvidually in games to 75Hz or they will still run at 60Hz and the colors will be washed out.Now onto the review*** REVIEW ***The screen resolution is full 1920x1080p at 75Hz, the colors are very accurate, it looks no where near like a TN panel, I would say its in between a TN panel and an IPS panel but closer to IPS.It comes with speakers which are ok for the price but I recommend headphones or your own speakers which are probably better if you got this for gaming.This is what comes in the package- Monitor- 4 screws for mounting- Two screws for setting up the monitor (non adjustable height(- HDMI to VGA cable- VGA to VGA cableI really recommend this monitor even if not for gaming, its a great price for what you get and it even comes with two cables.However one thing to note is that the difference between 60Hz and 75Hz is hard to notice in games. Playing Witcher 3 and Rise of Tomb Raider at locked in 75FPS wasn't anything much more amazing than 60FPS. However it is still an improvement.One last thing to confider if you’re debating on a 75Hz vs 144Hz monitor- If you have a graphics card such as the GTX 770,970,1060 Most games (witcher, call of duty, battlefield wont go back 80 fps on ultra / high graphics) so you wont be able to take advantage of a 144Hz monitor, so I suggest this one. UNLESS you play on medium/low settings.- If you have a graphics card such as a GTX 770,780,980,1070 and above, I suggest the 144Hz monitor since these can run most tiles at well above 100FPS so you can take advantage of the monitor.*** UPDATE ***Earlier on the review I said the difference between 60Hz and 75Hz was negligible, I take it back.I played on my laptop which is limited to 60Hz and it feels bad and slugish compared to 75Hz, once you go higher refresh rate you can never go backIts one of those things you dont realise until its taken away, great improvement.

If I fired it up, the screen Sceptre would turn red but it wouldn't start up. It would sometimes say that my USB wasn't plugged in. I tried both of the 2 ports but neither one worked. After fussing with it for 2 hours it still didn't work. So I thought it was my laptop who had a problem.  So I moved to a TV set with a USB port. It has an awesome screen but I can't spend hours to have another one break again.  My time is worth than the cost of the this whole monitor!  So, if you've got the time to make sure to get a good one and or won't throw it against the wall in  frustration, go ahead to buy one.

reviewDescription: I can easily fit this in my cabinet when it’s not in use while I’m gaming on my Xbox. Nice monitor for a good price!

My only complaint is the power button is a bit difficult to access considering it also controls screen setup. The built in audio is pretty good as well.

Ruined my other monitor when moving it, needed a nice replacement. For the price, it's worth it and I got to buy it on payments, so in a pinch, this was great. Trying to work or watch something and screen would go black then come back on and then go black again… sent in for warranty replacement and now they say it is not doing that. So my work computer is my notebook and when I'm at home I prefer to have it hooked to my monitor desktop monitor and rely on multi-channel peripherals, so switching between work and play is somewhat seamless. That's the background.So I don't have a lot of experience with desktop monitors (this is my second in about 3 years and the one I had before this was a cathode-ray monitor hooked up to my Windows Vista desktop) so you can take everything I say about picture, size, etc well salted. That being said, I actually love this thing.  It's a little on the large side for my tiny cubby of a desk, but it's great. The picture quality is great. I love playing video on it, all that good stuff. Also, having two HDMI connectors does not hurt when you're switching between screens. The bevel size is an improvement on my old monitor, but it comes with the drawbacks. The buttons for the monitor are located on the back, which is a design protocol that I hate, and always have hated, but that is neither here nor there. My problem is that markings on the front of the bevel, denoting which button is which, are nigh invisible. I can only see them if I move my body so that it's at a certain angle and I am staring straight at them. As such I prefer to go by feel, and I usually get it right. Switching between screens could be easier, and can't be done in less than three button pushes. It is stable: I've only had the screen crash once switching between my desktop and my laptop, and it's a lot easier to reset the connection when it's and HDMI cable as opposed to a DVI. All in all the negatives are minor for me, but I guess worth taking a star off. Still, I would recommend this if you're in the market for a cheap monitor.

reviewTitle: It's a good Monitor for the ~$100 price point
reviewDescription: I ordered this monitor because my old 30in cheapo tv finally took a crap, so I bought this and made it my main display making my LG Flatron W2246 my secondary display. It's not a terrible monitor for what you paid for. In some ways it's better than the LG in some ways, brighter whites and slightly more saturated darks. One issue I have with it is that I can't get the 75Hz refresh rate that is on the box and in the manual. Another issue I have is that it's not as crisp as the LG, when watching videos the image is slightly more crisp and cooler as far as color. Overall this monitor is a great beginner monitor if you buy it at the $90 that I did, just make sure that if you are running a dual monitor setup that you have a stand that let's you adjust the height of the monitors individually because the VESA mount is low on the monitor and that most likely will put it at a higher viewing angle than your other monitor... trust me I know.

One aggravating fault with this set.  Netflix and Hulu apps crash after a couple weeks using.  The only fix is go to settings, find apps in advanced settings, clear cache and data.  Great, it worked, but now have to login to apps again.  I have read if you don't update to latest firmware you won't experience the issue.  I dunno, I let it upgrade and am not sure I want to reset to defaults and skip the upgrade.  I suppose if I get aggravated enough I will try it.Enough rant about the single flaw.  Picture quality is awesome once correctly calibrated.  I love the android integration and simplicity connecting to my Samsung Note 10+.  The remote works great in spite the fact it feels like an empty shell.  No worries.  If you lose it you can operate it with your phone.  With voice if you want.  Upshot, for the money, in spite the one aggravation, I would definitely buy this set again.

reviewTitle: Mixed thoughts- price and size yes
reviewDescription: Well it’s not great and it’s not totally horrible. Sorry for the back and forth but the monitor is fulfilling the purpose I bought it for. You can’t expect this thing to be as great as an Samsung, Asus, etc.My work from home monitor replacement, yes I bought it myself because the company supplied 20” is way too small and old. This monitor works for desktop applications, and it’s so-so. I had one stuck pixel as did my best friend who followed suite in buying one too. Needs some tweaking but works great for my work needs. I thought about returning it over the one pixel but in reality the price and waiting another 2-3 weeks to receive a replacement not worth it with the Covid-prime  2weeks instead of 2 days shipping.Now for my other use, this work from home setup is a spare computer and if the wife takes my main game box I have a fall back. This monitor is horribly fuzzy and washed out in gaming. For the record I have only tried overwatch with a freesync compatible RX 550 4gb card ( it’s a dell tower not my ryzen 5 with 32gb ram and SSD drives upstairs).  So I know there’s a big difference but the image and colors can’t hold a candle to my acer 24.5” 75hz monitor with my game box. Does it work, yes absolutely well enough I can ignore the above and enjoy a game.If you want size, cost, and don’t care to game on this monitor it’s decent for the price. If you plan to game on it, I would suggest looking elsewhere. Unless you care more about size & price and can deal with it and the potential of a stuck/dead pixel you may get too.Nick

This is a fairly good 24" 1920x1080 60p monitor. Easily configurable to a myriad of needs.That said, it is a TOTAL PAIN to mount.Now, if you want to simply use the included pedestal base, fine. No problem, the installation is fairly simple and straightforward.The REAL problem comes when you want to use the VESA mount. I suppose if you intend to use a variable frame wall mount, it should go well. It's mounting on a swing arm bracket that proved difficult. If you do not have 1/2" spacers and long mounting screws, you will have to take more drastic measures to make the mounting plate fit properly. I need about 30 minutes, a Dremel-style power tool and a metal-cutting wheel to cut the pedestal mount bracket off, then, using a metal-grinding bit to smooth out the rough bits. If you do this carefully, it will go quickly and cleanly. You just have to be careful and TAKE YOUR TIME.Once I was able to mount mine, it worked beautifully from the minute I turned it on. It has a line of buttons up the right-hand rear, with the power button on the bottom.I have this connected to an Acer Nitro 5 17" tablet with dedicated nVidia GTX1650 4GB video card, so I can us my laptop with a wireless mouse and keyboard without squinting at a typical laptop display. I have it positioned, so that I can raise the lid without bumping into it. It is quite lightweight, as well.
There is no software for this.  You have to do all your configuration on the monitor controls.

reviewTitle: Good deal - speakers are the only disappointment
reviewDescription: I was looking for a good, inexpensive monitor for someone else and this fit the bill.The picture quality is fine for the specs given.  In fact, I was pleased to see a good tilt function and the HDMI cable included.  It  even includes a small screw driver for attaching the base.One minor item is that I wish the power switch had been on the front.  For the older, less tech savvy user, it can be good to have the power switch (and maybe others) on the front instead of tucked far behind on the back.  I had not thought of that while shopping.The bigger disappointment was the speakers.  I knew to not set high expectations but I thought for sure they would be better than a cheap laptop's speakers for youtube and zoom.  In fact, they were significantly worse than the 15" Dell Inspiron's built-in speakers.  For the older, hard of hearing person, this was quite a disappointment.I would say it is a good buy as long as you are not counting on the speakers.  I would have gladly traded the screwdriver and HDMI cables for slightly better speakers.Still, overall it exceeded expectations at this price point.

reviewTitle: Not a quality product, fresh out of the box
reviewDescription: I was so excited to find/receive this monitor for photo editing and webpage management, as I have been searching for the best bang for my buck.  I thought this was it! There was an option mentioned that was to use an ancient analog connector (not included), so that is no help either.  Returning this product and avoiding this off-brand product.

reviewTitle: Monitor speakers are useless. Often get "Out of range" notice.
reviewDescription: This monitor includes internal speakers. I thought I was going to be able to eliminate external speakers on my desk top to save space, but the highest volume of the internal speakers, which are in the back of the monitor, is so low that it is unusable for me, and I assume for many other people. I have had to disable the internal speakers and go back to the external speakers on top of my desk and taking up space. I have also had the monitor go black on several occasions with the notice, "Out of range." Very aggravating when on Zoom and losing the picture. Unplugging the HDMI cable and placing it into the other HDMI slot brings the picture back, until it happens again. In that way I have had to switch back and forth in HDMI slots.
After less than 2 years, the screen started to randomly not work. Some days it does, others it does not. Rebooting, changing cables, changing power source does not help

I liked most things about the monitor. But I did buy it primarily for gaming, and I am just a casual gamer. I see no need for external dedicated speakers or headphones most of the time.That said, I obviously do not expect the best of quality or anything fancy. But I do expect to be able to raise the volume to levels I can actually hear, and in many cases, the volume controls just BARELY even reach that. To top this off, higher pitched sounds will cause the speakers to screech.Yea, its volume barely reaches a normal low volume room level,... but it SCREECHES so badly it makes my ears feel like they are going to bleed. The last monitor I used had nothing like these kinds of issues.If you use headphones or speakers, this monitor might still work for you. But I am judging it as it is,.. it has speakers therefore I expect them to work to an adequate level. They do not.
